issues.body: In the section "Using SVCB with HTTPS and HTTP" the text says "NOT REQUIRED" and while I agree the upper case adds the gravitas, it's not a legit 2119 keyword.

comments.author: MikeBishop
comments.body:
Hm, I think that technically we want a "MAY not implement Alt-Svc," but the naive reading of that is that you're not allowed to implement.  "MAY choose not to implement Alt-Svc."

Alternatively, do we need 2119 language here?  "need not implement" would communicate the right message.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: My opinion is we don't need the 2119 language.  I was offering the option if the authors feel they want one.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: This can. be closed

issues.title: We should change master to primary in Appendix A.3
issues.author: moonshiner
issues.body: FYI, I was just thinking we should be ahead of this.

issues.title: Update document references
issues.author: moonshiner

comments.author: MikeBishop
comments.body: The doc just shouldn't reference specific version numbers at all unless we truly mean *that specific version and no other*; the build process will fetch the most current version of the document if not specified.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body:
Oh that makes perfect sense actually.  I was wondering why some references had versions and another did not. 

and I've gotten my tooling worked out.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: The we should remove the version numbers on those documents?

issues.title: SRV language is unnecesarily perjorative
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
> Address a set of long-standing issues due to HTTP(S) clients not implementing support for SRV records, as well as due to a limitation that a DNS name can not have both CNAME and NS RRs (as is the case for zone apex names)

This implies fault in clients for a refusal to implement, as opposed to SRV not providing sufficient advantages for HTTP(S) clients.

Rather than get into the why, it might be best to say which of the features of SRV are provided and why.  

I might also separate out the point about NS and CNAME not playing well together.

issues.title: EOFU: HSTS
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: HSTS is mentioned in Section 1.1, but it is not expanded or a citation provided.

issues.title: Non-normative normative language
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
Seciton 1.2 is explicitly non-normative (whatever that means), but it uses some language that looks very much like normative requirements:

> Clients must either use responses included in the additional section returned by the recursive resolver or perform necessary SVCB, A, and AAAA record resolutions.  DNS authoritative servers may attach in-bailiwick SVCB, A, AAAA, and CNAME records in the Additional Section to responses for a SVCB query.

The use of lowercase here means non-normative, but the choice of words is unfortunate.  Why not use different words:

> Clients either use responses included in the additional section returned by the recursive resolver or perform necessary SVCB, A, and AAAA record resolutions.  DNS authoritative servers can attach in-bailiwick SVCB, A, AAAA, and CNAME records in the Additional Section to responses for a SVCB query.

issues.title: Definition of "origin server"
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
> The "origin server" is the server that the client would reach when accessing the origin in the absence of the SVCB record or an HTTPS Alt-Svc.

HTTP has a definition of origin server that this is not compatible with.  In HTTP an "origin server" is a server that is authoritative.  As the goal of this document is to define alternative ways to reach a server that is authoritative, the definition this document uses is very confusing.

I don't have a solid alternative at this point, but I might suggest that the notion of "whatever you get when this record isn't used" isn't a very useful distinction.  As a hypothetical, consider a protocol that only uses SVCB derivatives for discovery, which would obviously have no such concept.  It might be better to dispense with the notion of "original server" entirely.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
One example of where this term is used:

> The "port" SvcParamKey defines the TCP or UDP port that should be used to contact this alternative service.  If this key is not present, clients SHALL use the origin server's port number.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
The only other place this is used is:
```
If none of the options succeed, the
       client SHOULD connect to the origin server directly.
```

It seems like this term is used sparsely enough it can be dispensed with, and the sentences reworded.

issues.title: 64k priorities!
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: I realize that this might be going against an established trend, but the notion that 65535 different values for priority might be useful is a little fanciful.  HTTP are proposing just 8, DSCP had 64, and neither has any real expectation that there will be any value in having all of those options.  Why not 255?

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
Mainly for consistency with existing DNS types.  MX, SRV, NAPTR, and URI all have a similar "Priority" or "Preference" field, and they are all 16-bit unsigned.

I don't have a use case for more than 255 values, but I wouldn't want to break the pattern without a positive signal from the DNS experts.  I'm happy to solicit input from DNSOP if you think it's worth changing.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: I'd argue for leaving this as-is. Is it more priorities than we need? Yes, but it also fits the existing DNS RR type implementations better.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body:
It's true that Priority/Preference fields are 16-bit unsigned, but based on 20yr old decisions. 
I don't think I have seen anyone using a value > 255, and this is from years of looking at DNS zone data. 
If it is left as is, I'd mention it's to align with those DNS RR Types.

comments.author: andrewtj
comments.body: It's odd to want to retain this for consistency with other types and also have no qualms about changing the meaning of the name ".".

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: I propose leaving this as 64k for consistency and closing.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: I've made a note to mention this when we do a WGLC to see what the WG says

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Given the code point assignment for the RR types and this being a wire-format change, we should either change this ASAP or leave it as-is.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Indeed. We can't really change this if we have the wire format stable. If we do anything, let's have editorial text explaining why it's a 16-bit field.

issues.title: ABNF for values
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
The definition of values allows for quoting, but the ABNF doesn't capture that.

```
   escaped-char  = "\" (VCHAR / WSP)
```

This implies that "\3" is valid, where it is not.  Capturing this is not so difficult.

```
   basic-visible = %x21 / %x23-27 / %x2A-3A / %x3C-5B / %x5D-7E
   unescaped = %x21 / %x23-27 / %x2A-2F / %x3C-5B / %x5D-7E
   escaped-number = (%x30-31 2DIGIT) / (%x32 (%x30-34 DIGIT) / (%x35 %x30-35))
   escaped-char  = "\" (unescaped / WSP / escaped-number)
```

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body:
should "%2A-3A" be " %x2A-3A" ?
same for " %2A-2F " ?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Edited to add the 'x'.  As I copied this, I hope that this wasn't something I copied in.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body:
I put a copy of the (updated) extracted ABNF in https://gist.github.com/moonshiner/3aa994227226c9e5b33dc808a8937574

This does run through 'bap' w/out errors.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body:
https://github.com/MikeBishop/dns-alt-svc/pull/160 updates the ABNF slightly.

Also, we have "key" and "display-key" but currently only use "display-key"

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body: For this issue, the relevant PR is #202.  PR #160 also makes some colliding changes, but it's not directly relevant to this issue.  If one of those PRs is approved, I'll merge it and resolve the collisions in the other PRs.

issues.title: Use colons before examples
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
Such as in:

```
   As an example, the owner of example.com could publish this record

   _8443._foo.api.example.com. 7200 IN SVCB 0 svc4.example.net.
```

Text forms don't have clear delineation of example and text and without a colon it is harder to read.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body:
https://github.com/MikeBishop/dns-alt-svc/pull/198

Should catch all those missing colons.  A double check before merging would be apprecriated

issues.title: Similar to CNAME
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
"When SvcRecordType is AliasForm, the SVCB record is to be treated similar to a CNAME alias pointing to SvcDomainName."

Is this normative?  Because it reads as being normative, then it uses squishy words.  I think that this sentence is for setting intent, and could be reworded.

issues.title: Aliases to A/AAAA records
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: It's not clear why this is useful as opposed to having a ServiceForm SVCB at the target of an alias.  Some words on the subject would be greatly appreciated.

comments.author: davidben
comments.body: It also, as I understand things, means a client which sees a chain of HTTPS alias forms must, at each stage in the process, issue new parallel A/AAAA/HTTPS queries since we can't assume that the three will get stapled together.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Is the wording following #209 good enough for us to close this?

issues.title: Step 3 of client algorithm, SHOULD?
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
> If one or more SVCB records of ServiceForm SvcRecordType are returned for HOST, clients should select the highest-priority option with acceptable parameters, 

Is this SHOULD select ?

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body: Sure, why not.  Added to #204.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Fixed in #204

issues.title: Privacy intent?
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
What does this mean (from S3.2)?

> Clients using a domain-oriented transport proxy like HTTP CONNECT ([RFC7231] Section 4.3.6) or SOCKS5 ([RFC1928]) SHOULD disable SVCB support if performing SVCB queries would violate the client's privacy intent.

It's not clear what information is leaking and to whom here.  This likely needs more text that addresses assumptions about where the client is sending these SVCB queries.

Of course, letting the proxy perform name resolution can improve privacy with respect to the resolver that a client chooses.  However, there are ways in which SVCB can enhance privacy in these configurations, especially if the proxy is not trusted with information about destinations.  It requires that you use DoT or DoH to a resolver that the client trusts to learn domain names.

issues.title: Mandating DoS
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
The text in Section 3.1 correctly identifies a number of ways in which a client might be denied access to a SVCB record.  I don't know if this is exhaustive, but it seems like a reasonable start.  It then mandates (using "MUST NOT") very specific behaviour.  That mandated behaviour ends up making the service effectively unreachable.

It is not appropriate for this document to set policy for clients in this way.  It is clear that this is biased toward ensuring that secured alternative methods for reaching a service are known to a client, but I don't think that this is the only way to achieve that goal.  All this does is make the system more likely to be brittle and prone to denial of service.

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
This is a "MUST NOT" because otherwise ECH is vulnerable to a downgrade attack: if a MITM between Firefox and the DoH server drops just the packets containing SVCB responses (likely identifiable by size or timing), they will eventually time out.  If the client falls back to ordinary connection, they'll lose the ECH protection.  (QUIC makes this attack especially easy.)

If ECH doesn't need to be downgrade-resistant in this way, then we can relax the requirement, but the ECH experts I've talked to seem to think that this threat type is in-scope.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Why make the requirement generic though?  There is already text in Section 8.1 that addresses the problem of ECH downgrade (though it is not complete, see #196).

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
I remembered another reason: the downgrade protection also applies to the HTTPS upgrade functionality, so fallback-on-error would allow the MITM to disable HTTPS upgrade.

An alternative to the current spec would be: "on error, the HTTPS upgrade still applies as if the record were present, and if the client supports ECH, it must abandon the connection entirely".  That seems like more spec complexity for very limited gain (assuming most clients do implement ECH), but I think it would be safe.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
We should not place any weight on this mechanism when it comes to downgrades.

I'm not suggesting that ECH advice needs to change (except as described in #196, perhaps), but instead suggesting that the generic advice not be so strong.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Proposal from discussion: change to SHOULD and then have text in security considerations saying why you REALLY OUGHT TO

issues.title: Presentation of ALPN
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: The presentation format for ALPN is not consistent with the generic presentation format.  It also includes unprintable characters.

comments.author: marka63
comments.body: Apart from having to recognise "\\," vs "," and having to remember which commas where escaped and which where not, APLN are still a optionally quoted string.  e.g. ALPN="x\\,y,z" or ALPN=x\\,y,z

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
It is unnecessarily different.  And it's not clear that the same escaping rules apply.  In the presentation format I might include \000 to include a literal NUL, but it appears to require the inclusion of a literal NUL preceded by a backslash in the ALPN format.

If the section said "just like the presentation format, but you have to escape comma" then it might be understandable, but the differences are inexplicable.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Larry Campbell (@lcampbel) also found this unclear in a thread on dnsop, so it does seem like we should clarify.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: How about a couple of examples?

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Fixed in #202.  Good enough now?

issues.title: Remove no-default-alpn
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
This is of no lasting value and it only represents a marginal gain in space for a non-trivial gain in complexity.  Having an ALPN field in every HTTPS record just isn't that many bytes (2+2+3=7 for just "h2", 2+2+3+9=16 for "h2,http/1.1").

I've raised this a couple of times in the past, but I never received a satisfactory response.

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
The goal here was not efficiency of encoding, it was to avoid a certain category of administrative mistakes.  Specifically, without this in place, it would be easy for a zone owner to add a single record with "alpn=h3 echconfig=...", test locally, see everything is working, and not realize that they just disabled their website for ~10% of users (who don't have UDP routability).

This represents something of a compromise between participants who wanted to be able to run QUIC and TCP on separate endpoints (or even QUIC-only services in unusual situations), and participants who wanted HTTPS-over-TCP to be required for every endpoint.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I don't find that sort of defensive design useful relative to the complexity it adds.  And it makes the configuration less transparent.

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
The `no-default-alpn` business is the result of a Very Long Debate that I would prefer not to reopen, but it's not something anyone is particularly happy with.  Currently, getting rid of it would result in records being unusable in the default state.  To fix this, we would have to give `alpn` a default value of `http/1.1` (for the HTTPS RR) if the key is absent.

In the design you're proposing, `alpn=h2` means that you dropped support for HTTP/1.1-only clients.  (I believe even Chrome is sometimes HTTP/1.1-only, e.g. for WebSockets).  That strikes me as more likely to result in swearing sysadmins than the current design, and same for the `alpn=h3` case.

To put it another way, I think there are likely to be many orders of magnitude more zone owners configuring these RRs than software developers implementing them, so we should prioritize the ease of (working) configuration over the ease of implementation.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
Would it be helpful to adjust the name of this parameter to make the effect more clear? For example, rather than `no-default-alpn`, you could call it `strict-alpn`, `restricted-alpn`, or something similar.

Making claims about what the default ALPN is might be causing some of the annoyance here. Instead, if we think of the list of ALPN values in the record as purely additive from the client’s perspective (always just a hint to add capability and never restrict), this key becomes a way to disable ‘additive’ mode and tell clients that the list is actually a hint of the only ALPNs that are supported.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Calling it strict-alpn or restricted-alpn would not be compatible with the changes in #201 .  Are there other names that might be less confusing?

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: In what way would those proposals not be compatible?

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
I think that should be #201.

"Strict" or "restricted" would seem to indicate that the client must not send anything other than listed ALPNs, or that the server won't accept anything else.  Neither of those readings match the intent of the ALPN selection process, in the current draft or in #201.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
#201 makes more sense =)

Yes, I agree that it's not "strict". It's mainly a hint that the old ALPNs won't work.

What is the client behavior intention here? As a client, I'm honestly just ignoring it right now. I guess it's a way to say, if you think you can get rid of h1/h2, then delay trying those?

comments.author: enygren
comments.body:
Example use-case would be having an RR set with two HTTPS records: one supports h1 and h2 and h3 and the other supports only h3.  The one with only h3 would have higher priority.  This would be to allow different service addresses (or different server pools) that are h3-only.  That may come in-hands as h3 opens up some interesting deployment possibilities. 
The concern is that having alpn=h3 mean h3-only is that if that's the only record included that it could be a foot-gun.  Thus "alpn=h3 no-default-alpn" still alows for h3-only but for a safer default on alpn=h3.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body:
Based on discussions, are there concerns about closing out this issue?
(While not perfect, this still seems like a reasonable compromise.)

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: "No" is hardly a compromise, but I can live with the outcome.

issues.title: Advice regarding construction of ALPN extension in TLS
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
>    Clients MUST include an "application_layer_protocol_negotiation" extension in their ClientHello with a ProtocolNameList that includes at least one ID from the ALPN set.  Clients SHOULD also include any other values that they support and could negotiate on that connection with equivalent or better security properties.  For example, if the ALPN set only contains "http/1.1", the client could include "http/1.1" and "h2" in the ProtocolNameList.

This could be read to imply that a client conditions its choice of ALPN parameter in a TLS ClientHello based on what it learns from SVCB.  This is dangerous as it exposes the connection to potential downgrade attacks.  Though it tries to recommend that "better" options be chosen, this is a determination that the server makes in ALPN, not the client.  This document should instead mandate that clients construct an ALPN extension containing all protocols that they are willing to use.

comments.author: MikeBishop
comments.body:
I think that depends on how you define "downgrade."  The existing text says that the client includes:
- At least one ALPN token from the SVCB record(s)
- Any protocol the client supports which it considers "better" than the least-preferable selected token, even if not in the SVCB record

But the point that it leads to selection involving the client's definition of "better" versus the server's is certainly a fair point.

comments.author: davidben
comments.body:
Wait, I remember this "better" formulation already came up and was rejected, for precisely this reason. The network does not get to influence the selected ALPN protocol. This notion of "better" breaks any formal notion of downgrade protection. It also has practical consequences beyond downgrades: even if client and server agree that h2 is better than http/1.1, the current draft text makes h2 SVCB into a deployment hazard if, say, the server needed to rollback h2.

I agree with Martin that this text needs to change. Both http/1.1 and h2 SVCB records must result in the *exact* same ALPN advertisement, namely all the client's accepted protocols. The only acceptable filtering is that inherent to collections of compatible ALPNs. Beyond that, SVCB stays out of the TLS ALPN negotation.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Merged in #201.  Good enough to close?

issues.title: Dual use of references symbolic names as words
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
As an editorial convention, this is hard to follow because the words used to identify a reference also form part of the sentence.

e.g., "CNAME or [DNAME]", "By removing the [Attrleaf] labels used in SVCB".

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: does "By removing the underscore-prefixed label used in SVCB"  sound better?

issues.title: Unclear precedence rules
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
At one level, the precedence rules for this specification could be simple: take the RRs with the lowest priority and select at random between them.  This is clearly the case for the 0/other split.

But it isn't that simple, because RRs with lower priority might not have options that the client supports.  So some configurations are eliminated.

Moreover, there are cases where server/operator preference and client preference might be in tension.  Let's say that the client greatly prefers HTTP/3 over HTTP/1.1.  Is it required to use an HTTPS RR with HTTP/1.1 and a lower priority if a higher priority supports HTTP/3?

More difficult, what if the higher priority has echconfig and the lower priority one does not?  Section 8.1 might be read to imply that echconfig overrides other considerations, but it isn't very clear on that point.  Also, we have to consider an echconfig that the client does not support specially, as that does not imply that the RR lacks echconfig.

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
Change #204 includes some changes that might make this clearer.  However, I think precedence rules are pretty clear: clients shuffle, sort, and walk down the list.  If they run out, they fall back to normal connection.  (Special case: if all attempts had ECH, and all failed, don't fall back to non-ECH.)

The order of attempts is SHOULD and MAY, so sufficiently smart/opinionated clients can mess with it if they want.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Is this good enough now that #204 has been merged?

issues.title: Period is owner name for additional section processing is different to every other type.
issues.author: marka63
issues.body:
For every other type the next name to be looked up is embedded in the rdata itself.  Additional "." often means "no such service".   For BIND adding "." is owner name meant touching 102 files as every other RR types method for processing additional data needed to changed as well as every place where additional data is added to the response.

I'm wondering if making "." special like this is worth it? 

I'm also wondering if we should be giving up the ability to signal "no such service" as is done in SRV, MX is worth it?

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
> For BIND adding "." is owner name meant touching 102 files as every other RR types method for processing additional data needed to changed

That's definitely surprising!  We didn't think this would be complicated to implement.

> I'm wondering if making "." special like this is worth it?

The most important thing to me is that we have a way to encourage SvcDomainName == owner name when editing the zone file, because this reduces latency under certain conditions.  Perhaps we could use `*` or `-` instead of `.` in the zone file.

Repeating the owner name, without the benefit of name compression, is a bit annoying.  Can you think of a way to avoid the duplication that would be easier for BIND?  It's too bad we don't have a name-compression mode that works within an RR.

> I'm also wondering if we should be giving up the ability to signal "no such service" as is done in SRV, MX is worth it?

I haven't heard anyone ask for this, so I don't consider it a priority.  If there's an easy way to signal it I'd be OK with including it, but we'd have to think carefully about what it means.  (If there's no HTTPS service, does that mean there's no HTTP service either? What if there are multiple RRs, and only one has this flag?)

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
Keeping the wire format small and simple for having the name match is important, so I think that part should stay as is. I don’t have much preference for the presentation format here. “.” makes sense by matching the normal interpretation of a zero-length label. However, some other presentation format symbol does as well here. 

For BIND, it’d be nice to hear more clarity for why this was complex. Can the parsing not easily be specialized per type?

As for communicating that there is no such service, I’d be concerned to see that for things like HTTPS. These are hints that should help upgrade connections to more secure mechanisms (ECH, HTTP/3, etc), but being able to say “don’t do https” or similar sounds problematic. Unless there’s a use case, I’d argue to leave such functionality off for now.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Would using something else with the same meaning help?  For example, "=" or "~" or "^" or something might avoid confusion with other uses of "."  (which would then just be a single label containing that character in the wire format).

comments.author: marka63
comments.body:
> > For BIND adding "." is owner name meant touching 102 files as every other RR types method for processing additional data needed to changed
> 
> That's definitely surprising! We didn't think this would be complicated to implement.

You changed the additional section processing paradigm.  Most of those 102 files was saying "the owner name is not used in this method".  Part of it was actually passing the name from higher up in the calling stack.  When a nameserver looks up the addresses associates with a NS record it doesn't care about the owner name of the NS record.  It just looks at the RDATA of the record.  The same applies for every other record except these two proposed ones.

https://gitlab.isc.org/isc-projects/bind9/-/merge_requests/2135/diffs?commit_id=232cb0d53bd3ba4f9b3fb0d80d903916b917627c

> > I'm wondering if making "." special like this is worth it?
> 
> The most important thing to me is that we have a way to encourage SvcDomainName == owner name when editing the zone file, because this reduces latency under certain conditions. Perhaps we could use `*` or `-` instead of `.` in the zone file.

You are assuming that it will take a lot of time for recursive servers to learn about these records.   That is not reality.
Some nameservers do speculative lookups of records missed (no RRset, no cached no data, no cached nxdomain) when doing additional section processing.  BIND does one lookup but it could be made to do more.

> Repeating the owner name, without the benefit of name compression, is a bit annoying. Can you think of a way to avoid the duplication that would be easier for BIND? It's too bad we don't have a name-compression mode that works within an RR.

Well if you really want it you would need to signal that the client supports intra RR compress for these types.  That is easy enough to do with a EDNS option (option code + list of types the client supports intra RR compression for).  You would need to get a label type assigned for intra RR compression pointers.   IANA already maintains a registry.  The server would need to do case sensitive compression to preserve DNSSEC signatures for when the record was returned to canonical form for DNSSEC processing.

https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml#dns-parameters-10

> > I'm also wondering if we should be giving up the ability to signal "no such service" as is done in SRV, MX is worth it?
> 
>  I haven't heard anyone ask for this, so I don't consider it a priority. If there's an easy way to signal it I'd be OK with including it, but we'd have to think carefully about what it means. (If there's no HTTPS service, does that mean there's no HTTP service either? What if there are multiple RRs, and only one has this flag?)

comments.author: bemasc

> Most of those 102 files was saying "the owner name is not used in this method".

Thanks for clarifying.  I presume you're referring to [this change](https://gitlab.isc.org/isc-projects/bind9/-/commit/232cb0d53bd3ba4f9b3fb0d80d903916b917627c) in your experimental branch.

I'm not familiar with the BIND code, but this seems like a reasonable implementation to me, and suggests that the current spec is not too bad.

> You are assuming that it will take a lot of time for recursive servers to learn about these records.

Mostly I'm just counting roundtrips.  SVCB queries are always issued in parallel to A/AAAA queries, so if SvcDomainName == owner-name, then there are already queries in flight for the necessary addresses (0 extra roundtrips).  Anything that requires a followup query, whether by the recursive or by the client, adds some amount of latency.

> Well if you really want it you would need to signal that the client supports intra RR compress for these types. That is easy enough to do with a EDNS option ...

If something like this already existed I think we would use it here, but inventing and standardizing it seems like a big project, not justified by the size of the problem.

I was thinking of something to avoid special-casing "." in this way, e.g. "The SvcDomainName is represented with a one-octet length prefix, followed by a buffer of that length.  The buffer contains a domain name that fills the buffer.  If the name is fully-qualified (ending in an empty label) then it is an absolute name; otherwise it is relative to the owner name.".  However, I expect this would make your implementation more complex, not less, so I'm not suggesting this change.

issues.title: Consistency for service/endpoint/origin naming
issues.author: enygren
issues.body:
In #204 there is a cleanup of "origin" for the non-HTTPS uses but it also highlights the need for consistent terminology and a terminology section (and terminology scrub).
It seems to land on:

* Service = the thing a Service owner wished to delegate.  ("Origin" is an HTTPS-specific instance.)
* (something? Endpoint Operator?  Service Operator Endpoint?) = the entity that operates a set of endpoints.
* Endpoint = the thing that gets bound to by an individual SVCB RR   (ie, a set of IPs which share a set of common configuration)

From this, AliasForm delegates a Service to an Endpoint Operator.
If we are consistent about this, ServiceForm would be better called EndpointForm.

issues.title: Relax "MUST NOT" on  target equalling owner name
issues.author: enygren
issues.body:
From @marka63:

Section 2.4.1.  AliasMode paragraph 2.  Why have "MUST NOT" here?                         

   The primary purpose of AliasMode is to allow aliasing at the zone
   apex, where CNAME is not allowed.  In AliasMode, TargetName MUST be
   the name of a domain that has SVCB, AAAA, or A records.  It MUST NOT

Nameservers and clients need to detect loops regardless of the number of

pulls.title: Recommend shuffling the RRSET
pulls.author: bemasc
pulls.body: Suggested by Shumon Huque: https://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/dnsop/current/msg23143.html

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
OK.  Could we say that the semantics are the same as getting multiple Alt-Svc response headers?

RFC 2616 says "Multiple message-header fields with the same field-name MAY be present in a message if and only if the entire field-value for that header field is defined as a comma-separated list [i.e., #(values)].  It MUST be possible to combine the multiple header fields into one "field-name: field-value" pair, without changing the semantics of the message, by appending each subsequent field-value to the first, each separated by a comma."

Alt-Svc says "When multiple values are present, the order of the values reflects the server's preference".

I think this is actually workable.  The server can produce multiple RRs, each of which can contain multiple options in preference order.  The DNS client will scramble them, and then HTTP will glue them together in that order.  Then the client will (probably) use the first one that's compatible.

More concerning, this raises the point that there's no defined behavior for what to do with these multiple records:  Fold them together, as multiple instances of the HTTP header would do?  (In which case order matters.)  Just take the first one?  Something else?

Once the client has connected to the server, if the server possesses a valid certificate, then it simply supplies the persistent record as an HTTP header.  If the server doesn’t possess a valid certificate, then the persistent entry will fail to connect anyway.
Given the requirement to only have one alias (2.4), perhaps it’s worth specifying that this is only applicable to the alt-svc form?

Information coming over an HTTPS connection is authenticated by the certificate, while DNS is potentially unauthenticated.  Records from an authenticated connection are always higher priority than those from DNS.

This is titled "Appendix," but is a top-level section in the body.  I'd suggest making each of these subsections an actual and separate appendix.

The concern here is about an active attacker on the local network who is also a pervasive passive adversary.  This attacker could inject a fraudulent DNS record that would then permit them to track that user even after they leave the network.  The adversary in this case is not the server operator.

For example, suppose there is a server operator who doesn't use Alt-Svc at all, and who serves the same domain on all IPs of a /64.  An adversary who can inject a long-TTL DNS record can pin a user to one of those IPs, and then reidentify that user across the internet whenever they visit that domain.  This can (and should) be solved by clearing the client's DNS cache when moving between networks.  Since DNS data in this case can be cached in the Alt-Svc cache, we need "persist=0" to get equivalent behavior.

EDIT: Persist=1 would also enable a persistent DoS by a network that wants to block access to some site.

I agree, how about
> clients SHOULD synthesize a new "ma" parameter from the DNS TTL if they intend to integrate with an Alt-Svc cache.

I think HSTS support here is important.  It's a rare chance to fix the "bare domain" bootstrap problem, and would win a lot of support for HTTPSSVC from parties who would otherwise not be very interested in this stuff.

I don't view opportunistic security as sufficient, and I think it's considerably more complicated than "HTTPSSVC requires HTTPS".

The browser folks I've talked to seemed particularly opposed to implementing any protocol that created mismatch between the SNI and the actual validation process, because of the potential for security bugs.

If the rule is "consume the first zero, ignore anything else" then you have an easy and deterministic rule.  Also, it makes it easy to roll out "1" by populating the new records prior to removing the old one.

And of course, something is better than nothing -- I'm amenable to other deterministic ways of selecting, but I'm less attracted to "pretend you didn't see it" as a mandated reaction.

The DoS issue is solved by Alt-Svc failing back to a direct connection if alternatives fail.  But the tracking argument is valid -- the attacker could just relay the packets to the real server, meaning the TLS handshake will complete (albeit with TLS RTT exceeding TCP's RTT from the client's point of view).

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
> I'm a little leery of assuming one feature supported means a different one isn't broken.

Supporting unknown RRTYPEs has been the standard [since 2003](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3597), and almost all servers do this correctly.  I don't think we need to accommodate servers who've implemented the still-rare standard from 2018 but not the near-universal one from 2003.  AFAIK, no such servers exist today, and once HTTPSSVC is widely deployed, anybody who tried to set up such a server would quickly figure out that it is seriously broken

Additionally, this accommodation is not the only reason to apply this logic.  If you don't have a secure connection to your recursive, then respecting SERVFAIL doesn't actually protect you from a network adversary (specifically an adversary between you and the recursive).  With a validating resolver and a secure connection, respecting SERVFAIL provides reliable protection (on signed domains).

> Perhaps a better approach is to synthesize an HSTS record just like we synthesize an Alt-Svc record and persist that independently of clearing the Alt-Svc records.

This approach is still opportunistic, not reliable against an active attacker.  It would also enable a persistent DoS by a transient local network adversary (as with persist=1).  I think this functionality is better served by the existing `Strict-Transport-Security` header, which can be set securely by the site itself on first access.

Presumably this could also happen for servers that are misbehaving and don't understand the HTTPSSVC record type in the query?  I think we'd need more data an implementation experience.  Perhaps we could reword this as a MAY?  (Or put in Security Considerations?)

Yeah, it depends on how much faith the client has in their resolver.  I would be OK with conditioning this on a secure transport to the resolver (as a proxy for "decent resolver, won't SERVFAIL on new RRTYPEs").
OK, I've updated this PR to only apply to "cryptographically protected connections".  Please review.

Perhaps a better approach is to synthesize an HSTS record just like we synthesize an Alt-Svc record and persist that independently of clearing the Alt-Svc records.  That way, if the client has ever seen the record, then they'll be secure in the future regardless of attacks against their DNS server?

... "or are received as part of the reponses to the AAAA and/or A queries that were issued-in-parallel."

Add:  "When the SvcDomainNames and any needed HTTPSSVC records are available, these client SHOULD make subsequent requests over connections specified by the HTTPSSVC records."

(I suspect that for transitional purposes the A/AAAA record alongside the origin domains in these cases will provide sub-par performance relative to the target of the HTTPSSVC record.)

The issue is that Alt-Svc and HTTPSSVC are "optional", and connection can always continue without them.  This text is intended to clarify that while their presence is optional (NXDOMAIN isn't a problem), certain failure modes should be treated as fatal, even if the connection actually would complete successfully if the client ignored the error, because this category of errors might represent adversary trying to force a downgrade.

Admittedly, this particular text is mostly academic/optimistic, since very few clients (and AFAIK no commercially deployed clients) actually validate DNSSEC on the client.

comments.body: I've substantially changed the proposal here, incorporating your CNAME idea and also making "SvcRecordType = 0" optional for the client (since it doesn't have any security implication).
Does it?  I'd think with the source-address-token-validation it's the same number of RTTs for a cold client as the TCP+TLS 1.3 1RTT flow?  (Perhaps I'm misremembering.)

Do we want to mention my hack here?  (That clients SHOULD look at the set of aliases / canonical names in the A/AAAA response chain to see if they have an A/AAAA resolution of the SvcDomainName in this recent response?)  And that operators may choose to have the SvcDomainName match a name that the client would see a resolution for as part of the A/AAAA lookup?

DNS RTTs and Origin RTTs often have no relation and may be orders of magnitude different.  (The former may have cache miss impact and server processing time overhead, but there are also plenty of cases where the DNS recursive is close to the client and the origin is far away, or vice-versa.)
That's true, but I thought most servers were expected not to perform that kind of validation unless an attack is detected.
I think that's worth mentioning somewhere.  The client behavior might just be "decent DNS cache" behavior.

Yeah, they're not well-correlated.  The main point here is to find a way to make the average net performance loss negligible (or even a net win), even on legacy recursives (which will surely be prevalent for many years).  My sense is that an acceptable solution:

1. Can't impose a latency-proportional average-case delay on any large category of connections.
2. Must provide security features reliably or not at all.

I'm certainly open to alternative solutions if you don't think this one will be convincing.  I just don't have any other good ideas for how to square this.

pulls.title: Ban fallback when ESNI is enabled
pulls.author: bemasc

comments.body: Are there any caveats we'd want?  Such as for clients that don't care about the privacy benefits of ESNI?  (Does the ESNI spec itself allow for any fallbacks?) This otherwise seems generally reasonable.

Why would a client that doesn't care about the privacy benefits of ESNI use ESNI?  Maybe the phrasing is unclear, but my goal was to specify that if the client cared enough to encrypt the SNI on the first try, then it shouldn't send un-encrypted SNI on the second try.

EDIT: To your second point, the ESNI folks are working on error-recovery, but not "fallback" to a non-ESNI connection.

For one thing, to contribute to the overall prevalence of ESNI on the Internet, reducing the odds that it stands out as unusual.  A client that will use ESNI when possible, but doesn't really care whether it's used in any particular instance, seems entirely plausible.

An ESNI fallback behavior creates an incentive for a network adversary to block connections with ESNI, to force a retry without ESNI and reveal the name.  (If only some clients have fallback it's generally easy to target them, because most TLS clients have a distinctive ClientHello due to cipher and extension choices and ordering.)

ESNI is not designed to be opportunistic, and I don't think the TLS group would approve of a document that introduced that kind of behavior.  I'd rather have clients behave consistently, either implementing ESNI support or not.

Bottom line: "MUST" is used when the consequences of failure to comply are serious (and perhaps non-obvious).  I think this situation deserves a MUST.
I think it's reasonable to include this and then discuss with a broader audience?

Although one reason to *not* have this as a MUST:  at least one use-case I've been interested in getting implemented is to do ESNI for just HTTP/3 QUIC (as there's lots of value in trying to prevent middle boxes from messing with ESNI).  This isn't possible if doing so prevents QUIC fallback to HTTP/2 (which is necessary). 

Would an additional attribute indicating the ESNI is opportunistic and fallback is allowed be a compromise?  "esnioppt=1"?

What a mess.  @MikeBishop, what is the exact semantics of unknown parameters in Alt-Svc?  If a client sees an alt-value with "esnikeys", and doesn't know what that parameter is for, does it ignore the parameter or the whole alt-value?
From rfc7838:  "Unknown parameters MUST be ignored.  That is, the values (alt-value) they appear in MUST be processed as if the unknown parameter was not present."
OK, I've added a way to let server operators choose opportunistic ESNI.  Please review.
Sounds good.

comments.body:
Reading through both the Abstract and the Intro, it would be nice to edit these a bit more heavily for length:
- Abstract is quite long, would be nice to be one paragraph (minus the parts that will be removed)
- While the note in the abstract does explain the name, it may be nice to explain a bit. Especially since SVCB isn't really obvious as a name.
- The abstract mentions enhancements to performance and privacy, but these aren't summarized at all in the intro. I'd expect some explanation here to enhance the "why should I care".

Thanks for the reference!

As a nit, missing a period at the end of the sentence:
```suggestion
use an approach such as {{!HappyEyeballsV2=RFC8305}}.
```

```suggestion
The SvcParamKey for ESNI is "esnikeys".  Its value is defined in
```
Done and done.

reviews.author: enygren
reviews.body: This looks generally quite good!  See a bunch of questions throughout, although many are just ideas/suggestions/clarifications and some we can defer for later.  I'm also going to submit a PR against this from enygren-svcb-generalization-2 with a bunch of additional minor edits.

comments.body: Do we still want to mention extensibility somewhere in the intro?  I think that would be helpful to give context for some of the design decisions.  (ie, that this also may allow future use-cases to be covered without needing to add additional DNS lookups.)
It only is functionally equivalent for the services it specifies.  Hence why the "for alternative service endpoints including HTTPS" was there.  Is there a better way to phrase this compactly?

Do we want to include all of ALPHA or just:

          ALPHA_LC          =  %x61-7A   ;  a-z

?  (Since case insensitive.)

"SHOULD NOT "?
Should clients use the first or last instance of a parameter that violates this and appears more than once if the specification doesn't allow this?  Perhaps MUST use just the first?

Isn't it possible that it can contain all of these? 
Perhaps:

> The SvcDomainName MUST point to a domain name that contains
> another SVCB record, address (AAAA and/or A) records,
> or both address records and a ServiceForm SVCB record.

Should we have something more consistent here?  For example:

> Unless specified otherwise by the protocol mapping, clients MUST ignore
> SvcFieldValue parameters that they do not understand.

Adding an example here would be helpful.  For example:

> For example, in the following example "svc2.example.net"
> is the effective SvcDomainName:
> 
>     www.example.com.  7200  IN HTTPSSVC svc.example.net.
>     svc.example.net.  7200  IN CNAME    svc2.example.net.
>     svc2.example.net. 7200  IN HTTPSSVC 0 . ( alpn=h2
>                                          port=8002 esnikeys="..." )
>     svc2.example.net. 300   IN A         192.0.2.2
>     svc2.example.net. 300   IN AAAA      2001:db8::2
Is the duplicate SvcFieldValue a typo?

Meta:  

I guess we should pick "an SVCB" or "a SVCB" and then replace consistently throughout. Which depends on whether it is pronounced "a Service B record" or "an S.V.C.B. record".
Should we rename this as "proto"?  That might be more human-friendly?

Should we allow multiple "alpn" entries?  One specific use-case would be to allow both h2 and http1.1 to be listed compactly as options in the same entry, which might be a common case?  (In this case, the first one listed should be defined to take preference.)  Or is this too much complexity?
Do we want to exclude "a" and "aaaa" from this?  (If anything, the defined format won't work within Alt-Svc.)
Do we not need any of this?
Do we want a column for "Repeats" to indicate whether it is allowed to repeat?  (Or maybe just leave that with the definition?)
(This is included in my PR)
OK, I've modified this text to note that.
Clarified.
Done
Resolved in your edit
Done
Fixed in your edit.

I think "proto" sounds like something that would apply to any "protocol" that uses SVCB, but in fact this field is specific to TLS-based protocols.  For example, one might be tempted to use "proto=ssh" for a SVCB-for-SSH, but of course that is nonsense.

If you want we could change it to "tls-proto", but I think "ALPN" is the usual nomenclature in the TLS and HTTP world.

I see the appeal, but I'd rather preserve the 1:1 mapping with Alt-Svc.  Allowing multiple ALPNs significantly complicates the Alt-Svc synthesis algorithm.

In practice, I think the only ALPNs in play are "h2" and "h3", so we're not talking about an enormous amount of duplication.

They are excluded by virtue of not having a defined mapping.  However, I don't want to rule out a future draft defining a mapping.

I think the format will work fine in Alt-Svc; it just requires quotes around the value.

On closer inspection, it looks like I lost the bit about the trailing ".".  I added that back in.

I tried to remove the parts of this section that were restating information that was already defined: our resolution procedure, the conceptual mapping in `#map2altsvc`, and the Alt-Svc syntax from RFC 7838.  I think we should lean toward brevity until we get a request for clarification.

I did preserve the portion about ordering, which did not appear to be duplicated anywhere else.
I don't think it's necessary at this time.
There was only one instance of "a SVCB", so I went with the majority.
It sounds like you want registered keys to be lower-case, but display-form to be case-insensitive.  I attempted to capture that.

pulls.title: Proposed edits to Ben's edits.  Most are minor.
pulls.author: enygren
pulls.body: Minor typo fixes and edits.  Add proxy behavior.  Add a/aaaa param clarifications.

reviews.author: bemasc
reviews.body: I have some thoughts on the substantive changes but I'll propose further revisions in another PR.

comments.body: It sounds like you are proposing to chase the SVCB chain outside the proxy, and then use the final SvcDomainName in the request-target.  That seems like a fine idea to me, but I think the recommendation should be weaker.  I don't want anyone to think that we're telling them to leak DNS queries to an untrusted resolver when using a proxy for privacy purposes.
I think this requirement already exists, regardless of whether the client is IPv6-only.

Mention "unless SVCB queries are also issued via the proxy (eg, via DoH)"?

Part of the need to specify the proxy behavior is to get ESNI to work properly.  Should we spell this out here (to explain why this proxy behavior is important), or perhaps later?  ie, part of getting ESNI to work means the keys and SvcDomainName corresponding to the connect need to match up.

I'm still solidly in the "if you are skipping your local DNS resolver's DNS64, you MUST do rfc7050 synthesis" camp.  There are tens (hundreds?) of millions of mobile end-users who will be broken otherwise for IPv4-only sites.  An alternative would be to say that a "aaaa" parameter MUST be included if an "a" parameter is present?  (Which puts the onus on the server-side.)  If we don't have a MUST on the client or the server, recursive resolvers will do DNS64 synthesis here so having a MUST NOT there is unrealistic.
OK, I added an explanation of motivations for the proxy section.

> I'm still solidly in the "if you are skipping your local DNS resolver's DNS64, you MUST do rfc7050 synthesis" camp.

Me too.

> There are tens (hundreds?) of millions of mobile end-users who will be broken otherwise for IPv4-only sites.

I don't think anyone will be broken, because the alternative is to just ignore address hints you can't use.

> If we don't have a MUST on the client or the server...

We have a MUST on the client: "clients MUST perform A and/or AAAA queries for SvcDomainName as in {{client-behavior}}"

Good point.  So perhaps:

When only "a" parameters are present, IPv6-only clients may either synthesize IPv6 addresses as specified in {{!RFC7050}} or fall back to resolving SvcDomainName. To avoid this, "aaaa" parameters SHOULD be published whenever "a" parameters are published.

?

Sounds good.  Do we want to highlight that proxies trying to do content filtering and assuming that what they are connecting to is the Host/SNI could get confused?  (Which are the same proxies that ESNI will make sad.)
Works for me.
I'd rather leave that alone if possible.  Using an "affiliated resolver" as described would cover that use case.

OK, I added a version of this.  Note that "fallback" is probably not an accurate depiction of what's going on here: the AAAA query MUST be issued regardless, and SHOULD be used as soon as it's ready, so the only question is whether to wait for it.

pulls.title: Clarify racing behavior for A/AAAA and SVCB parallel queries. Give rationale to A/AAAA answer preference.
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body:
We have text in the ESNI draft which describes what to do when A/AAAA arrives before ESNI (equivalently SVCB). This attempts to port that text over. Please have a look!

@enygren @MikeBishop @bemasc

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body: Thanks for identifying this optimization and writing it up!
Since you pronounce this "Ess Vee Cee Bee" it should remain "an"

The current logic just requires the client to wait for the SVCB response.  As you note, the SVCB response contains security-relevant information, so it's important not to miss it.

Is the goal here to handle [DNS non-response](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-dnsop-no-response-issue-13)?  Even the most ancient DNS servers will return an error if there is a problem with the SVCB query.  Total non-response is a serious bug, but it does happen.

As that draft notes, the client [can measure this behavior](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-dnsop-no-response-issue-13#section-3.1.2).  If you think it's worth documenting a solution for this case, I'd prefer that approach, and I'd suggest doing it in a separate "Compatibility" section.
I think this would have a very high false-positive rate due to iterative lookups required to walk the SVCB chain.

> Is the goal here to handle DNS non-response?

Not quite! The goal is to handle answers received out of order. It’s an optimization.

This is the delay in waiting for the first SVCB response, not the delay in abandoning ESNI altogether. The value is meant to give the SVCB answer time to arrive since, presumably, clients would prefer using that over the A/AAAA answer(s). Maybe I’m misunderstanding your point.

This should also reference {#optimizations} and also allow the use of responses in the client DNS cache, not just hints.  In-particular due to this it may often be possible that the hint values aren't needed if the SvcDomainName already has valid A/AAAA records in-cache (eg, due to being part of the CNAME chain from the A/AAAA lookups issued in-parallel):

> To avoid a delay for clients using a nonconforming recursive resolver, domain owners SHOULD use a single SVCB record whose SvcDomainName is in the origin hostname's CNAME chain if possible. This will ensure that the required address records are already present in the client's DNS cache as part of the responses to the address queries that were issued in parallel.
Typo.  s/SVCR/SVCB/
Will fix!
Yes, great point! I'll specify that cached answers are viable. (This content already exists in the {#optimizations} section, so a citation seems redundant?)

OK.  As your text notes, SVCB covers a variety of transports and use cases, so I think we need to express this with more generality, like:
> If an A or AAAA response arrives before an SVCB response, the client MAY begin connection as if the SVCB query returned NODATA, but MUST NOT transmit any information that could be altered by an SVCB response until the SVCB response arrives. For example, ...(esni)... .

And then separately
> If an SVCB RR is consistent with an active or in-progress connection, the client MAY prefer that RR.
OK, got it.
Excellent suggestion! I tweaked your proposed text and added it. Please have a look!
I think "ClientHello" would be clearer than "connection"
I think changing between "RR" and "record" in this sentence is slightly confusing.
Maybe "in-progress TCP connection"?  "proceed on that socket"?  Also might want to mention ports...
I would prefer a definition of "consistent" where the SVCB record is also consistent with a socket if the AAAA for SvcDomainName matches the socket's IP.
This requirement is already present in the definition of `ipv*hint`.  Can we find a way to avoid having to repeat it?
I didn't want to bubble up too much of TLS, but if you're fine with it, that works for me!
I'll stick with record! (And I'll make that change in the rest of this section, too.)
I think a simplification is, "TLS should proceed on that connection," so we don't need to get into socket or port details. Does that work?

Hmm... is it? The paragraph here aims to say that if the hints are *not* present, then (1) look in the cache or (2) try to resolve. The definition of `ipv*hint` doesn't seem to cover this case since it assumes they're present, right?
Agreed -- I made an attempt at adding one. Please have a look!

Maybe it would be clearer to say
> if an SVCB record arrives with an "esnikeys" value and an IP address from "ipv6hint" or an attached AAAA record that matches an in-progress connection, ...

That doesn't cover every case it but clarifies what is meant by "consistent".
This definition is good but it leaves out ports and IP hints.
I don't think this paragraph is necessary.  The relevant requirements are already laid out in `{client-behavior}` and `{svcparamkeys-iphints}`.

The normative force here is unclear.  Is optimistic pre-connection RECOMMENDED?  What does it mean to wait for "up to CD milliseconds"?

I would prefer for optimistic pre-connection to be OPTIONAL.

As mentioned above, I don't think `{svcparamkeys-iphints}` handles this case. (It handles the opposite one, namely, where hints are present.) I think it's important to include this case (paragraph) to be complete.
I think this is OBE.

SHOULD and RECOMMENDED are the same per RFC2119, right? I'm fine bumping it down to optional advice, since it truly is optional.

> What does it mean to wait for "up to CD milliseconds"?

Is "wait up to CD milliseconds before connecting" not clear? It means, "don't try and connect until CD ms go by." How can we make this more clear?

I can add ports, but I don't think IP hints are part of the definition. (Or, rather, they don't change things.) There's two cases for hints:

1. The hints match C's address: Continue using C's address.
2. The hints do not match C's address: The definition of the hints says that C's address should be used since it corresponds to the A/AAAA of SvcDomainName.

So I left them out and just included the port.

"SHOULD wait ... before connecting" is ambiguous.  Is it "SHOULD wait and SHOULD connect" or "MAY connect but SHOULD wait"?  I would prefer the latter.  If indirection (non-empty SvcDomainName) turns out to be the most common reason why SVCB is slow, the success rate for this trick might be too low to justify the complexity.

It sounds like "wait *at least* CD milliseconds" would better capture your meaning.

Under the current definition, this record is not consistent with this socket.  The IP hint matches, but consistency is defined in terms of the address record, not the IP hint.

I think we should fix this by changing the definition, e.g.
> An SVCB record is consistent with an active or in-progress connection if the client would attempt an equivalent connection when making use of that record.

Could you help me understand what the new requirement is here?  Or could we simplify this to "If the SVCB record is not consistent with ... clients must proceed as described in step 3 of `{{client-behavior}}`.

> It sounds like "wait at least CD milliseconds" would better capture your meaning.
 
Indeed it would! I'll use that.
Simplifying like so is perfectly fine by me! I wanted to keep the blurb to close the dangling "else" case in this section. Good suggestion. :)
Fixed -- thanks!

@tfpauly, you can also pronounce it "Service Bee," in which case it's "a".  Ah, the linguistic implications of how we read acronyms....

Unless we're going to specify a pronunciation in the draft?  Would have headed off a whole lot of "giff/jiff" nonsense.

reviews.author: MikeBishop
reviews.body: Looks good.

comments.body: Might want to just rewrap the paragraph.
Done

comments.body:
Do we still need to declare that SvcFieldValue must be empty for AliasForm?  Or that clients must ignore SvcFieldValue in AliasForm?

Generally I worry a little about overloading SvcFieldPriority...

My thought is to lean toward "clients must ignore", which is already implicit in the client behavior specification.  That would be forward-compatible if we eventually discover a use for SvcFieldValue in AliasForm.

I admit that this proposal special-cases "0", but I think "0 is special" is an ancient CS tradition.  I particularly like that clients can just sort by priority and then walk down the sorted list in a simple way.

Thanks for the reviews.

> unless we want to just call it "esni" ?

I would be OK with renaming to "esni", but I do wonder if it could be confusing, because the contents of this field are not the "encrypted SNI".  I would defer to the ESNI authors on preferred terminology.

It occurs to me that a client with multiple `ESNIConfig`s could potentially have some kind of fallback behavior (but how does that interact with `esni_retry_request`?) or it could even put multiple `encrypted_server_name` extensions in the ClientHello.

pulls.title: Remove recommendation to shorten the TTL
pulls.author: bemasc
pulls.body:
Shortening the TTL doesn't actually solve the problem,
because some caches ignore small TTL values.  Regardless of TTL,
servers have to be able to deal with occasional use of expired
records.  Shortening TTL is also bad for efficiency, so we
shouldn't encourage it.

Fixes #74

comments.body: "MUST NOT" seems wrong here.  Maybe this can be non-normative operational guidance or SHOULD NOT.

reviews.author: enygren
reviews.body: Change "MUST NOT" to something softer and then this looks good to merge.

comments.body: Agreed, especially as ESNI key rotations need to assume that clients will at least eventually re-resolve and not extend the lifetime indefinitely.  Perhaps "[...], so server operators should assume that clients will continue to use records for some amount of time past their expiration."   ?
I've adjusted the advice here.  PTAL.

Do we want to call out ESNI keys as well?

"Instead, server operators SHOULD continue operating the endpoints listed in expired records until they
observe that nearly all existing and new connections have migrated to the new endpoints (and are using new ESNI keys if applicable)."
I tried to capture this by changing the text to describe "configurations" instead of "endpoints".

It may be that neither is possible?)    Also, is there a distinction to be made here between NODATA/NOERROR (the RRType doesn't exist) and NXDOMAIN? > Is the negative behavior actually possible?

I think it might be possible, but it's definitely not straightforward.  It would require the client to recapitulate the recursive resolution procedure, notice the absence of certain RRSets, and check for a corresponding SOA instead.  It's more obviously possible (but even more complicated) for signed zones.

Anyway, I've significantly reworked this section to try to pin down the precise behavior of which records go where, what RCODE to return, etc.

Perhaps add:

"Recursive resolvers MAY respond to the SVCB Answer with 
only a subset of Additional RRs when the response would
be larger than is permitted or when responding before fully chasing 
dependencies would improve performance.  Additional information from
higher priority ServiceForm records SHOULD be prioritized over lower priority
ServiceForm records."
OK.  I added this to the Performance Optimizations section.

pulls.title: Replace "alpn" with "proto"/"no-proto"
pulls.author: bemasc
pulls.body:
This change
1. Makes it difficult for admins to accidentally drop support for HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2
2. Makes it easy for clients to determine the precise set of a protocols supported by an endpoint before attempting a connection.

Fixes #73

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body: @enygren @MikeBishop I've updated this PR to reflect our conversation today.  PTAL.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Documenting here that I think we're leaning in the direction of transport/no-default-transport and will reject this alternate PR?

What about DoH that mandates H2 support?  It also is entirely reasonable for service endpoints to support QUIC and not H2 or HTTP/1.1.  There are features of QUIC that make it attractive to have it on separate IPs that are QUIC-only.

Special-casing http/1.1 seems reasonable, but I'm not sure this is the easiest way.  
Perhaps:
A service endpoint supporting "h2" SHOULD also support "http/1.1" unless either no service endpoints support "http/1.1" or a distinct service endpoint is specified for "http/1.1"

?

> What about DoH that mandates H2 support?

DoH doesn't recommend refusing connections over HTTP/1.1, so I don't think there's a conflict.

> There are features of QUIC that make it attractive to have it on separate IPs that are QUIC-only.

I'd be really interested to know more about this use case.  I've been hearing concerns from browser people that support for QUIC-only endpoints may be difficult to implement, because it complicates TCP fallback when UDP is failing.  I'm hoping that we can find a middle ground that addresses both needs.  (Feel free to switch to email if it's too long for this comment thread.)
